text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 21.5.7, Account Resolution, Payment Tracers.
IRM 21.5.7.3.5 Updated to include an instruction to input an IDRS history item when sending a Form 8765 to Unidentiﬁed Remittance or Excess Collections. IPU 21U1263 issued 11-16-2021

IRM 21.5.7.3.10(4) Removed the author’s e-mail address and replaced it with an E-FAX number for monitoring Forms 4442 sent to ERS for payments cashed using all zeroes as the TIN. IPU 22U0793 issued 07-08-2022
IRM 21.5.7.3.11 Created new subsection to address unprocessed remittances. IPU 21U1263 issued
IRM 21.5.7.4.7.20 Updated the links to the Direct Pay IRM. IPU 22U0349 issued 03-08-2022
Various editorial changes were made throughout this IRM; cross-references were added, removed or revised as appropriate.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 21.5.7 dated August 31, 2021 (effective October 1, 2021) is superseded. This IRM incorporates IRM Procedural Updates (IPUs) issued between November 16, 2021 and July 8, 2022: 21U1263, 22U0349, 22U0554, and 22U0793.
AUDIENCE
All employees performing account work in Wage and Investment, Small Business/Self-Employed, Tax-Exempt/Government Entities.

) A payment tracer is the process used to locate a missing or misapplied payment. A missing payment is one that cannot be found on the taxpayer’s account. A payment tracer case is not resolved until the missing or payment is correctly applied to a taxpayer’s account. (

) Various research tools can help ﬁnd missing payments as described in the paragraphs below. Use of the Integrated Automation Technologies (IAT) such as the TC (Transaction Code) Search Tool is highly recommended. to Exhibit
, Accounts Management Mandated IAT Tools, for more mation. (
) Before disclosing any tax information: a. Ensure you’re speaking with the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s authorized representative. Refer to IRM
, General Disclosure Guidelines, more information. b. Review procedures in IRM

, Leaving Information on Answering Machines/Voice Mail, before leaving a message on the tax- payer’s answering machine or voice mail. c. Review procedures in Faxing before faxing conﬁdential information to taxpayer. (

, the “Check Clearing for the
st Century Act” or “Check

,” is a federal law passed by the U. S. Government. A “substitute check” is the legal equivalent of the original check and must be processed as if it is the original. Not all banks have the equipment needed to accept electronic payment ﬁles and “Check

” overcomes this obstacle. The trun- cating bank (which may be any bank in the check collection process) elec- tronically transmits an image of the front and back (including endorsements) of the original check and the recipient bank converts the information into a new form of paper instrument, known as a “substitute check.” A substitute check is the same size as the original and is designed to be processed in a bank’s sorting equipment just as though it is the original check and may be returned to the payer with the monthly bank statements. The check’s legend states “This is a legal copy of your check. You can use it the same way you would use the original check.” (

) When performing a query (research) for records, enter as much information possible to narrow your research request. A query initiated with minimal infor- mation may produce too many unrelated results. However, the quality of the information versus the quantity of information input into the query will the best results. (
) Only payments processed by banks after installation and programming of the RTR equipment are available. (

) Access Notes to view record changes or deletions made to either an record or a block of records prior to posting to Master File. For example, if a payment goes unpostable, the notes in RTR should contain enough informa- tion to allow users to track the payment record to the point at which it posts a taxpayer’s account. Once posted, changes or movement of credits are tracked through Master File via Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS). (

) The Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing (ISRP) System converts paper tax and information documents, and remittances received by IRS into perfected electronic records of taxpayer data. When a tax document received, it is opened and sorted by form type (e.g., Form
, etc.). Remit- and tances with their accompanying documentation are pre-sorted into groups called batches. Each batch is uniquely identiﬁed by a
-digit Remittance cessing System Identiﬁcation (RPSID) number. This number always begins with “
”, followed by six digits, followed by “

” This system captures, stores, retrieves, and archives (vouchers and check images) and routes data to downstream processing activities which subsequently post to the tax- payer’s account on Master File. (
) Effective November

, the ISRP processing of remittances has moved to electronic processing through the Treasury OTCnet system. The check data uploaded to OTCnet daily and from OTCnet to the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland (FRB-C). Refer to IRM

It is a web-based system that enables AM Campus Submission Processing (SP) campuses, and TAC offices to electronically process paper remittances at the point of receipt. Payments processed RS-PCC include those received in areas of the AM Campus Support (Andover, Atlanta, Brookhaven, Memphis, and Philadelphia) such as

vency, Offer In Compromise (OIC), and Mis-directed payments, as well as payments for Offshore Voluntary Disclosure Program (OVDP) received at the Austin SP campus and payments received at Field Assistance (FA) TAC offices. (

) Payments processed through RS-PCC are scanned and electronically sent to the Bureau of the Fiscal Service (BFS) Over the Counter Channel Application (OTCnet) for deposit. RS-PCC interfaces with the Electronic Federal Payment Posting System (EFPPS), which allows the taxpayer’s payment information to post to Master File. The OTCnet system is a Treasury department system because it is a treasury system the disclosure rules prohibit the actual tax account/TIN information from being communicated, therefore the tax account/ TIN/tracer ID information is redacted and will not be visible on the copy sent the taxpayer/ﬁnancial institution. You will need to access the RTR database using the payment date and amount (and if available the routing number) to retrieve the TIN and tax account information to determine the disposition/ application of the payment. ) Restitution is a legal remedy that can be ordered by the court, in a criminal case. A restitution order requires the criminal defendant to pay money or render services to victims in order to redress the loss the defendant has inﬂicted. Normally imposed during sentencing, it can be agreed to by the parties in a plea agreement or imposed as a condition of probation or super- vised release. (

) Restitution is generally limited to losses caused by the offense(s) of The major exception to this general rule is in cases involving plea The parties to a plea agreement in any criminal tax case may agree to tion in an amount greater than the loss attributable to the offense(s). (
) For restitution orders entered after August
, IRC

(a) was amended to allow the IRS to assess and collect the amount of restitution ordered in a criminal case for failure to pay any tax imposed by the IRC in same manner as if such amount is a tax. Prior to the amendment, IRS could not take administrative collection action to collect the restitution amount the tax was assessed in a separate civil proceeding.

) Conditions of probation and restitution ordered in a document signed by the judge are called Judgment and Commitment orders. Judgment and Commit- ment Orders normally specify that defendants must submit restitution to the office of the clerk of court in the district in which the defendant was sentenced. This generally includes restitution payments required to be paid to the IRS. (

) The clerk of court has the responsibility for receiving, processing, and recording restitution payments made by defendants. The clerk of court forwards the money (Treasury checks, personal checks, and/or money order) to the victim(s) listed in the restitution order, which may include the IRS. Criminal restitution payments made to the IRS should be mailed to the below. (
) The clerk of court offices disburses criminal restitution payments to the IRS by issuing Treasury checks to the IRS. Effective October
